awd_titl_txt: Standard Research Grant: Contending with Metrics in the Corporate Food Supply Chain
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

This research project studies food supply chains with a focus on the shift from certifiable standards of food quality and safety to metrics of ecological efficiency; the shift may be characterized more abstractly as a move away from ensuring compliance to promoting ongoing measurable improvement. The primary goal of the project is to understand the driving forces and implications of this shift. It will test two related hypotheses. First, that the shift aims to produce common global knowledge about what sustainability means in food supply chains, including how it can be measured and improved, and that it does so in order to address growing concerns about sustained access to agricultural raw materials. Second, the need to promote measurable improvement requires global food companies to contend with the local environments, practices, and knowledge of suppliers in new ways, and that doing so has the potential to reshape corporate food supply chain governance on a global scale. Reflexive engagement with pertinent supply chain actors will encourage broadened perspectives on all sides. The results of the study will be widely disseminated in both scholarly and trade publications and presentations, which will further enhance the prospects for positive change.

Technical Summary 

Employing multi-sited ethnography and drawing together scholarship on supply chains, standards, and corporate knowledge production, the project will examine the emergence of metrics-based governance both in multi-stakeholder initiatives and in the corporate food supply chains where mid-level sustainability managers work to enlist a wide range of other actors in their efforts to measure and achieve improvement. The project includes a pilot study of dairy farmers, who have become central targets of industry projects to assess and improve. The PI has existing contacts and has recently established access to the Sustainability Consortium, which will greatly facilitate carrying out the project. The project brings researchers in STS and political ecology into closer conversation and it does so in a new empirical terrain. While both fields have explored the production and governing power of standards, this project brings them together to analyze the rise of outcome-based metrics as tools of private food governance. The project draws insights from STS to examine how meanings and metrics of sustainability are co-produced in different social settings, and to trace how they are deployed and perhaps contested across space and supply chains. Following political ecology, the project analyzes the emergence of metrics-based governance in light of broader political-economic and environmental conditions. In doing so, this research considers how the situated, sociotechnical work of making metrics actionable, particularly at the farm level, could in itself lead to changes in how governance works.

por.por_cntn:
The project examined the efforts of major food companies to assess and improve the sustainability of the farms that supply their raw materials. At a time of growing awareness about agriculture's large environmental footprint, many "Big Food" manufacturers and retailers were publicly committing to timebound, quantitative goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and resource use in their agricultural supply chains. However, most of the companies that set these goals had no direct relations with or control over the farms producing commodity raw materials such as corn, soy and wheat. How then to assess their sustainability, and make sure it improved over time? To address this challenge, many companies joined multi-stakeholder initiatives (MSIs) where, along with non-governmental organizations, farmers' organizations, and a variety of experts, they developed sustainability metrics as well as tools for collecting the relevant data from farmers. These initiatives started from the assumption that the very practice of metrics-based assessment would drive improvement, especially given the collective power of participating companies. But progress proved much slower than expected, and this project helped to show why.

The project methodology combined participant observation at two major MSIs' meetings and events and in-depth interviews with more than 50 participants, most of them sustainability managers for large food manufacturers, retailers, or commodity trading companies.  The project found that many major food brands are now genuinely concerned about climate change and other environmental risks to the security of their raw material supplies. Contrary to popular conceptions of "Big Food," then, such companies' sustainability initiatives are not solely about brand image. On the other hand, neither companies' concern nor their power as major corporations guarantee the success of those initiatives. Especially in supply chains where farmers produce and sell their crops independently rather than through contract arrangements --which is the case for U.S. commodities such as corn and wheat--not even the biggest of Big Food companies can either dictate farming practices or demand that farmers share information about them. And relatively few farmers volunteer such information, partly due to concerns about how it might be used, and partly because they do not necessarily share companies' ideas about sustainable agriculture. Companies intent on knowing (and showing) that their agricultural raw materials are becoming measurably more sustainable, then, have had to invest more time, personnel and other resources in winning farmers' cooperation.

With these findings, the project has advanced understanding about both the limits of corporate power and the limits of metrics as private sector tools for improving agricultural sustainability. These limits in turn underscore the continued importance of the government's role in both regulating agricultural resource use and providing the resources needed to support environmentally as well as economically sustainable farming livelihoods.
